author: potuz
content: I am very afraid of all the designs for ILs and the runtime check required for IL satisfaction. This applies just as much as in 7547 with the tx invalidation issue as with Focil since a tx can be invalidated in the current slot by other txs in the IL. In 7547 the attesters can make certain that the IL is executable at the tob but this is not the case in focil so that the IL aggregate can contain txs that themselves invalidate some. When checking for IL satisfaction, this adds a runtime overhead to the EL. Blob txs add an extra difficulty that the DA may not be available at all and I don't think we are even remotely close to solve this issue as opposed to <@792404665068158998> and <@725415098331430932> above. I honestly think the txs invalidation issue is more subtle and serious than what most are thinking

author: potuz
content: I really think the tx invalidation issue is serious enough without the DA issue. But more importantly: forward ILs therefore have the exact same overhead to validate since validators will have to anyway run these checks for the same IL txs. This tells me that if we're willing to accept this overhead, then we should go with forward ILs instead of same slot (focil or not) because they don't have the timing tradeoffs

author: potuz
content: But that's the point, that you cannot know this statically, you need to check for this at runtime. This is the problem of tx invalidation that we had in 7547 and that I claim that focil doesn't solve. So if we're faced with this problem anyway then we may as well use forward ILs that don't suffer from removing time from payload validation
